definitions: Adapted to a purpose or environment.
Kept or reared for breeding, said of animals.
Showing anger or indignation, especially at something unjust or wrong.
Inclined to resent, who tends to harbor resentment, when wronged.
Harboring resentment, full of resentment, at a given moment.
Having an acrid taste (usually from a basic substance).
Enraged; infuriated; spitefully or furiously angry.
Causing pain or discomfort; painfully sensitive.
Sensitive; tender; easily pained, grieved, or vexed; very susceptible of irritation.
Feeling animosity towards someone; annoyed or angered.
Suffering from frustration; dissatisfied, agitated, and/or discontent because one is unable to perform an action or fulfill a desire.
Having greed; consumed by selfish desires.
Tending to match as much text as possible.
(of an algorithm) That tries to find the global optimum by finding the local optimum at each stage.
Eager to go to war, warlike.
(by extension) Aggressively hostile, eager to fight.
Not pleased or happy with something.
Discouraging; causing annoyance or anger by excessive difficulty
Filled with, or showing, spite; having a desire to annoy or harm.
Possessed of great wrath; very angry.
Feeling or exhibiting envy; jealously desiring the excellence or good fortune of another; maliciously grudging
Having been the subject of aggravation; frustrated and angry.
Annoying, troublesome, irritating (usually of an animal or child).
Of, pertaining to, or as a result of malice or spite
Evil or malignant in disposition, nature, intent or influence.
Troubled, irritated by something unwanted or unliked (an annoyance); vexed.
So angry that one turns pale; very angry; furious.
Unpleasant, foul (of odour, taste, mood, weather, etc.).
Producing or threatening sorrow, distress, injury, or calamity; unpropitious; calamitous.
Having harmful qualities; not good; worthless or deleterious.
(said about a wound or a rash) Inflamed and painful.
(said about the elements, like the sky or the sea) Dark and stormy, menacing.
Having a tendency to seek revenge when wronged, vengeful.
Causing irritation or annoyance; troublesome; vexatious.
Having or displaying ill will; wishing harm on others
Having an evil or harmful influence
Suspecting rivalry in love; troubled by worries that one might have been replaced in someone's affections; suspicious of a lover's or spouse's fidelity.
Protective, zealously guarding, careful in the protection of something one has or appreciates.
Envious; feeling resentful or angered toward someone for a perceived advantage or success, material or otherwise.
(chiefly US; informal in UK) Angry, annoyed.
Extremely foolish or unwise; irrational; imprudent.
(usually with for or about) Extremely enthusiastic about; crazy about; infatuated with; overcome with desire for.
(of animals) Abnormally ferocious or furious; or, rabid, affected with rabies.
(chiefly Northeastern US) Intensifier, signifies an abundance or high quality of a thing; very, much or many.
(of a compass needle) Having impaired polarity.
Not friendly, appropriate to an enemy; showing the disposition of an enemy; showing ill will and malevolence, or a desire to thwart and injure
Filled with, characterized by or expressing fury.
Characterized by aggression; unjustly attacking; prone to behave in a way that involves attacking or arguing.
Of heuristics, source code optimization techniques, etc.: exploiting every opportunity to be applied.
(of a tumour or disease) That spreads quickly or extensively; virulent; malignant.
Rushing with impetuosity; moving with violence.
Angered, made furious, made full of rage.
Pale, without redness or glare; said of a flame.
Supportive of, run by (a member of), pertaining to, or dominated by a political party represented by the colour blue.
Of the higher-frequency region of the part of the electromagnetic spectrum which is relevant in the specific observation.
(of steak) Extra rare; left very raw and cold.
(of a dog or cat) Having a coat of fur of a slaty gray shade.
Severe or overly strict in morals; gloomy.
Having a color charge of blue.
Suffering from boredom; mildly annoyed and restless through having nothing to do
Perforated by a hole or holes (through bioerosion or other)
Situated close to, or even below, the ground or another normal reference plane; not high or lofty.
Of less than normal height; below the average or normal level from which elevation is measured.
Not high in status, esteem or rank, dignity, or quality. (Compare vulgar.)
Disparaging; assigning little value or excellence.
Lacking health or vitality, strength or vivacity; feeble; weak.
Small, not high (in amount or quantity, value, force, energy, etc).
Simple in complexity or development; (in several set phrases) favoring simplicity; (see e.g. low church, Low Tory).
(in several set phrases) Being near the equator.
(acoustics) Grave in pitch, due to being produced by relatively slow vibrations (wave oscillations); flat.
Made with a relatively large opening between the tongue and the palate; made with (part of) the tongue positioned low in the mouth, relative to the palate.
Lesser in value than other cards, denominations, suits, etc.
Not rich or seasoned; offering the minimum of nutritional requirements; plain, simple.
(of an automobile, gear, etc) Designed for a slow (or the slowest) speed.
Affected with great sadness or depression.
Without energy, gusto or drive, enervated, without the will to accomplish, disheartened.
Having lost confidence or hope; dejected; disheartened.
Filled with or affected by melancholy—great sadness or depression, especially of a thoughtful or introspective nature.
Made unfit for habitation or use because of neglect, destruction etc.
(normally in the combination 'down with') Sick or ill.
At a lower level than before.
Having a lower score than an opponent.
Inoperable; out of order; out of service.
Finished (of a task); defeated or dealt with (of an opponent or obstacle); elapsed (of time). Often coupled with to go (remaining).
(police, of a person) Wounded and unable to move normally, or killed.
(of an aircraft) Mechanically failed, collided, shot down, or otherwise suddenly unable to fly.
Thoroughly practiced, learned or memorised; mastered. (Compare down pat.)
Accepted or respected, especially in the black or thug community.
Sated, having had one's fill; satisfied, weary.
Causing a person to lose heart; making despondent or gloomy.
With no or few possessions or money, particularly in relation to contemporaries who do have them.
Free from self-assertion; not proud or arrogant; meek.
(of a person) Regretful for an action; grieved or saddened, especially by the loss of something or someone.
Pathetic and inferior to the point of causing others disgust.
Sincerely penitent or feeling regret or sorrow, especially for one’s own actions; apologetic.
In low spirits from loss of hope or courage.
Having an absolute or (more often) relative lack of light.
(of colour) Dull or deeper in hue; not bright or light.
Without moral or spiritual light; sinister, malign.
Conducive to hopelessness; depressing or bleak.
Lacking progress in science or the arts; said of a time period.
With emphasis placed on the unpleasant aspects of life; said of a work of fiction, a work of nonfiction presented in narrative form or a portion of either.
Not very illuminated; dim because of darkness, especially when appearing depressing or frightening.
Unable to act without help; needing help; feeble.
From which there is no possibility of being saved.
(of a person) exhibiting sorrow; dejected; distraught.
(of a person) Feeling or filled with remorse.
Causing, feeling, or expressing regret or sorrow, especially in a wry or humorous way.
Affected by depression, depressed; dispirited; melancholic.
Relating to or characteristic of depression.
Filled with grief or sadness; being in a state in which one mourns.
Suffering damaging effects of economic recession.
Sad, discouraged, in low spirits, unhappy, having no hope
In a state of misery: very sad, ill, or poor.
Arousing scornful pity or contempt, often due to miserable inadequacy.
Weighed down with a load, burdened.
In the form of an adsorbate or adduct.
Having suffered the death of a loved one
Full of feelings of regret, indulging in regrets.
Sorrowful about what has been lost or done.
Dismal and gloomy, cold and forbidding
(of a person) Pained by the loss of someone.
Deprived of, lacking, stripped of, robbed of.
So appalling or sad that one feels or should feel sorry for it; eliciting pity.
Of an amount or number: very small.
Feeling or showing sorrow for wrongdoing.
Dull or dark in colour or brightness.
Accompanied by tears; crying, or about to cry.
Abandoned by a deity or god.
Feeling pain or sorrow on account of one's sins or offenses; feeling sincere guilt.
Full of woe; sorrowful; distressed with grief or calamity.
Causing a reduction in economic activity.
Very miserable; feeling deep affliction or distress.
Worthless; paltry; very poor or mean; miserable.
Used to express dislike of or annoyance towards the mentioned thing.
Miserable, as when lonely after being abandoned.
Weighing heavily on the spirit; intense, or overwhelming
Hot and humid of the weather.
Grieved and disappointed, especially with the loss of a beloved person or thing, such as the repudiation of a romantic relationship.
Unhealthy; liable to cause health problems.
Not behaving; behaving badly; misbehaving; mischievous or disobedient.
Unskilled; of limited ability; not good.
(of a need, want, or pain) Severe, urgent.
(of a draft/check) Not covered by funds on account.
Deserving strong condemnation; shockingly bad, wretched.
Lamentable, to be felt sorrow for, worthy of compassion.
Judged to have committed a crime.
(of a property) offered for sale after foreclosure
(of furniture, etc.) faded or abused in order to appear old, or antique
That causes great grief, anguish or distress.
Of, or relating to tyranny or a tyrant.
Providing physical comfort and ease; agreeable.
In a state of comfort and content.
Not remote in degree, kindred, circumstances, etc.; closely allied; intimate.
Without cares or worries; free of concern or worries; without difficulty.
Lacking in force (usually strength) or ability.
Unable to sustain a great weight, pressure, or strain.
Unable to withstand temptation, urgency, persuasion, etc.; easily impressed, moved, or overcome; accessible; vulnerable.
Dilute, lacking in taste or potency.
(grammar) Displaying a particular kind of inflection, including:
That does not ionize completely into anions and cations in a solution.
One of the four fundamental forces associated with nuclear decay.
Having a narrow range of logical consequences; narrowly applicable. (Often contrasted with a strong statement which implies it.)
Resulting from, or indicating, lack of judgment, discernment, or firmness; unwise; hence, foolish.
Not having power to convince; not supported by force of reason or truth; unsustained.
Not prevalent or effective, or not felt to be prevalent; not potent; feeble.
Having a temperature slightly higher than usual, but still pleasant; mildly hot.
Caring and friendly, of relations to another person.
Having a color in the red-orange-yellow part of the visible electromagnetic spectrum.
Close, often used in the context of a game in which "warm" and "cold" are used to indicate nearness to the goal.
Fresh, of a scent; still able to be traced.
Communicating a sense of comfort, ease, or pleasantness
Well off as to property, or in good circumstances; rich.
Strongly emotionally attached; very fond of someone or something.
Existing as a part or portion; incomplete
Describing a property that holds only when an algorithm terminates
Biased in favor of a person, side, or point of view, especially when dealing with a competition or dispute
(followed by the preposition to) having a predilection for something
Of or relating to a partial derivative or partial differential
Of or pertaining to a brother or brothers.
Of or pertaining to a fraternity.
Of twins or embryos, produced from two different eggs and sperm, and genetically distinct.
(of weather or a day) Featuring a lot of sunshine.
(of a place) Receiving a lot of sunshine.
(of a person or a person's mood) cheerful
Of or relating to the sun; proceeding from, or resembling the sun; shiny; radiant.
(when with and) Very, extremely. See good and.
Having a purpose or character of a charity.
Convenient or at a suitable time; opportune.
Generally warm, approachable and easy to relate with in character.
Having an easy or accepting relationship with something.
Promoting the good of any person; favourable; propitious.
Of or pertaining to friendlies (friendly noun sense 2, below). Also applied to other bipolar confrontations, such as team sports
Being or relating to two or more natural numbers with a common abundancy.
(in compounds) Compatible with, or not damaging to (the compounded noun).
Having a disposition to do good.
Possessing or manifesting love for mankind.
Altruistic, charitable, good, just and fair.
(of a person) Having affection or warm regard; loving; fond.
(of an action, etc.) Characterised by or proceeding from affection; indicating love; tender.
Eager; passionate; strongly inclined toward something.
(of an investment) having risen in value
Of, related to, showing, or characterized by sympathy
Relating to the sympathetic nervous system
Relating to sounds induced by vibrations conveyed through a fluid or gas from a body already in vibration.
Of magic, a supernatural connection or power resulting from two items having the same form or some other correspondence.
Agreeable; giving pleasure, cheer, enjoyment or gratification.
Uncritically satisfied with oneself or one's achievements; smug.
Apathetic with regard to an apparent need or problem.
Enthusiastic; keen; eager; showing great interest in something or desire to do something
Serving, intended or wishing to protect
Pertaining to the astrological influence of the planet Jupiter; having the characteristics of a person under such influence (see sense 1).
(of a person) Having qualities tending to result in being liked; friendly, personable.
Sensitive or painful to the touch.
Easily bruised or injured; not firm or hard; delicate.
Physically weak; not able to endure hardship.
Sensible to impression and pain; easily pained.
Adapted to excite feeling or sympathy; expressive of the softer passions; pathetic.
Apt to give pain; causing grief or pain; delicate.
Heeling over too easily when under sail; said of a vessel.
Careful to keep inviolate, or not to injure; used with of.
Of or dealing with languages or cultures derived from Roman influence and Latin: Italian, French, Portuguese, Spanish, Romanian, Catalan, Occitan, Corsican, etc.
Of a work of literature, a writer etc.: being like or having the characteristics of a romance, or poetic tale of a mythic or quasi-historical time; fantastic.
Fantastic, unrealistic (of an idea etc.); fanciful, sentimental, impractical (of a person).
Having the qualities of romance (in the sense of something appealing deeply to the imagination); invoking on a powerfully sentimental idea of life; evocative, atmospheric.
Pertaining to an idealised form of love (originally, as might be felt by the heroes of a romance); conducive to romance; loving, affectionate.
Irritatingly pleased with oneself, offensively self-complacent, self-satisfied.
Studiously neat or nice, especially in dress; spruce; affectedly precise; smooth and prim.
Done to satisfaction; adequate or sufficient.
Causing satisfaction; agreeable or pleasant; satisfying.
Making atonement for a sin; expiatory.
Under a magic spell (cast by a charm); bewitched.
Impressed by the pleasantness of something.
Of a particle: having nonzero charm.
Worthy of commendation; deserving praise; admirable, creditable, or meritorious.
Of, pertaining to, or being an empath: of or having the capability of sensing the emotions of others.
Deserving of the highest esteem or admiration.
(chiefly with of) Having a liking or affection (for).
That satisfies, gratifies or pleases; that removes any feeling of lack.
Expressing a large amount of love to other people; affectionate.
Very funny; causing great merriment and laughter.
Used as respectful form of address for a person or body of persons, especially in the name of a livery company. For example, Most Worshipful Grand Master of the Orange Order in Ireland.
(often sarcastic) In a good mood, happy, cheerful.
Relatively large in scale, size, extent, number (i.e. having many parts or members) or duration (i.e. relatively long); very big.
Of larger size or more importance than others of its kind.
(qualifying nouns of family relationship) Involving more generations than the qualified word implies — as many extra generations as repetitions of the word great (from 1510s). [see Derived terms]
(followed by 'with') Pregnant; large with young; full of.
(except with 'friend' and similar words such as 'mate','buddy') Intimate; familiar.
Of significant importance or consequence; important.
(applied to actions, thoughts and feelings) Arising from or possessing idealism; admirable; superior; commanding; heroic; illustrious; eminent.
(applied to persons) Endowed with extraordinary powers; of exceptional talents or achievements; uncommonly gifted; able to accomplish vast results; remarkable; strong; powerful; mighty; noble.
Title referring to an important leader.
Doing or exemplifying (a characteristic or pursuit) on a large scale; active or enthusiastic.
Intensifying a word or expression, used in mild oaths.
Inclined or having a propensity to love, or to sexual enjoyment.
Of or relating to, or produced by, love.
Affected with love; in love; enamored.
Having the ability to enchant; charming, delightful.
Feeling honoured (by something); feeling happy or satisfied about an event or fact; gratified.
Possessed of a due sense of what one deserves or is worth.
Having too high an opinion of oneself; arrogant, supercilious.
Generating a sense of pride; being a cause for pride.
(Of things) standing upwards as in the manner of a proud person; stately or majestic.
Excited by sexual desire; specifically of a female animal: in heat.
Full of merriment and high spirits; jovial.
Full of life and mirth; jouous; merry.
Often with a prepositional phrase, or with to and an infinitive: showing a quick and ardent responsiveness or willingness; eager, enthusiastic, interested.
Having a fine edge or point; sharp.
Acute of mind, having or expressing mental acuteness; penetrating, sharp.
Of cold, wind, etc.: cutting, penetrating, piercing, sharp.
Of prices, extremely low as to be competitive.
Jolly and full of high spirits.
Festive and full of fun and laughter.
Causing laughter, mirth, gladness, or delight.
Having a feeling arising from a consciousness of well-being or of enjoyment; enjoying good of any kind, such as comfort, peace, or tranquillity; blissful, contented, joyous.
Experiencing the effect of favourable fortune; favored by fortune or luck; fortunate, lucky, propitious.
Content, satisfied (with or to do something); having no objection (to something).
(Of acts, speech, etc.) Appropriate, apt, felicitous.
(in combination) Favoring or inclined to use.
(of people, often followed by "at" or "in") Dexterous, ready, skilful.
Having the atmosphere, decoration, or attitude of a festival, holiday, or celebration.
Having a bright or cheerful appearance; expressing or exciting joy; producing gladness.
Desirous; keen to do or obtain something.
Not employing lazy evaluation; calculating results immediately, rather than deferring calculation until they are required.
Full of zeal; ardent, fervent; exhibiting enthusiasm or strong passion.
Having the characteristics of a riot
Causing, inciting or taking part in a riot
Unrestrained and boisterous; degenerate or dissolute
(of a liquid) Boiling or agitated as if boiling.
Loud, sharp, and piercing to the ear.
Effeminate, flamboyant or otherwise obviously gay.
Feeling great well-being or elation or intense happiness; characterized by euphoria
Extremely happy and excited; delighted; pleased, euphoric.
"Cool"; meeting a certain hip standard or garnering the approval of a certain peer group.
Unofficial, informal, unauthorized, but acting as though it were.
Having power or influence, but not widely known or recognized.
Acting in a leadership role before being formally recognized.
Part of, or related to, the opposition in government.
Lacking kindness, sympathy, benevolence, gratitude, or similar; cruel, harsh or unjust; ungrateful.
Not kind; contrary to nature or type; unnatural.
Having no race or kindred; childless.
Anticipating something with anxiety or fear.
Perceptive; quick to learn; capable of understanding using one's intellect.
Displeasing to the eye; not aesthetically pleasing.
Displeasing to the ear or some other sense.
Offensive to one's sensibilities or morality.
Unpleasant; disagreeable; likely to cause trouble or loss.
Without feeling, emotion, or concern for others; uncaring.
Warning of bad consequences: ill-boding; portentous.
Requiring action to prevent bad consequences: urgent, pressing.
Of ominous significance; serving as an ill omen; foretelling of harm or difficulty.
Having a very unpleasant or frightening sound
Full of something causing fright, whether
Tending to inspire horror; that horrifies; horrific.
Held or lifted up; held or prevented from proceeding.
Expressing, or proceeding from, suspense or doubt.
(usually used predicatively, not attributively, be afraid) Impressed with fear or apprehension; in fear.
(used with for) Worried about, feeling concern for, fearing for (someone or something).
Causing fear or horror; appalling, terrible.
Inspiring awe; filling with profound reverence or respect; profoundly impressive.
Full of something causing dread, whether
Dreadful; causing terror, alarm and fear; awesome
Intense; extreme in degree or extent.
Without pity or compassion; cruel, pitiless.
Intentionally causing or reveling in pain and suffering; merciless, heartless.
Having a feeling of anxiety or disquietude; extremely concerned, especially about something that will happen in the future or that is unknown.
(of things) Accompanied with, or causing, anxiety; worrying.
Showing no mercy; cruel and pitiless.
Of fear, fright etc: sudden or overwhelming (attributed by the ancient Greeks to the influence of Pan).
Having, or prone to having hysterics.
Of, or relating to a mythical monster; full of monsters.
Violating morality or decency; provoking indignation or affront.
Experiencing or in a state of panic.
Causing or able to cause fright.
Subject to sudden alarm; easily frightened.
Causing fear; of capable of causing fear; scary.
Situated on the top of something.
Best; of the highest quality or rank.
Very good, of high quality, power, or rank.
Lacking in intelligence or exhibiting the quality of having been done by someone lacking in intelligence.
Characterized by or in a state of stupor; paralysed.
Lacking sensation; inanimate; destitute of consciousness; insensate.
Dulled in feeling or sensation; torpid
Exciting wonder or surprise; astonishing; wonderful; delightful.
Terrifying, causing terror; terrible; sublime, awe-inspiring.
Very strong or intense; excessive, tremendous.
Unable to act or respond; dazed; shocked.
Existing in or constructed from fantasy; of or relating to fantasy; fanciful.
Not believable; implausible; seemingly only possible in fantasy.
Resembling fantasies in irregularity, caprice, or eccentricity; irregular; grotesque.
Wonderful; marvelous; excellent; extraordinarily good or great (used especially as an intensifier).
In a state of shock or confusion.
Astonished, amazed or so suddenly surprised as to be unable to speak.
Filled or overcome with awe or wonder.
Tending to excite wonder; surprising, extraordinary.
Surprisingly excellent; very good or admirable, extremely impressive.
Astonished; confounded with fear, surprise, or wonder; greatly surprised. The following adposition may be: at, with or by.
Causing wonder and amazement; very surprising.
Caused to feel surprise, amazement or wonder, or showing an emotion due to an unexpected event.
Notable for its size, power, or excellence.
Extremely large (in amount, extent, degree, etc.) or great
Tired of or annoyed by something.
Failing to sustain adequate harvests of crop, usually specified.
Covered with, or containing unclean matter; dirty.
(of words or a way of speaking) obscene, vulgar or abusive.
(of the weather) Unpleasant, stormy or rainy.
Dishonest or not conforming to the established rules and customs of a game, conflict, test, etc.
Entangled and therefore restricting free movement, not clear.
Outside of the base lines; in foul territory.
Tending or able to repel; driving back.
Causing physical or mental repulsion; horrid.
Experiencing or causing nausea or uneasiness, often characterized by an unsettled stomach.
Tending or able to repel; driving back.
Having a bad or foul taste.
Arousing or meriting strong dislike, aversion, or intense displeasure.
Offensive or repulsive; arousing disgust or aversion.
Offensive to current standards of decency or morality.
Inconsistent with, or far removed from, something; strongly opposed
Abhorring; detesting; having or showing abhorrence; loathing.
Tending to rouse aversion or to repulse
Of something highly offensive; causing aversion or disgust.
Causing offense; arousing a visceral reaction of disgust, anger, or hatred.
Relating to an offense or attack, as opposed to defensive.
Having to do with play directed at scoring.
